bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to James E. Peabody, January 6, 1942

div1.p: Hench discusses plans for a memorial at Camp Lazear.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to James E. Peabody, January 6, 1942
div1.opener:
January 6, 1942
Dr. James E. Peabody
281 Lowell Ave.
Newtonville, Massachusetts
My dear Peabody:
div1.p:
I must apologize sincerely for not having answered your letter of December
14 earlier. The reason I delayed was that I am in the process of negotiating or
rather trying to negotiate with the present owner of the Camp Lazear site. He sold
me the little building but wants $2500.00 for the rest of the camp site. It would
cost at least $10,000.00 to build an appropriate building to enclose Building No. 1
and the question is whether this building should be left on the site of Camp Lazear
or, as the Cuban authorities want me to do, whether it should be moved to the false
site where Dr. Lazear died. The Cubans, as you know, are very lackadaisical in matters
of correspondence. Some of them just never answer my letters at all, some take weeks
before answering. The owner of Camp Lazear has been very gracious, when I finally
actually met him, but has been very tardy in answering. I still have not heard but
expect to hear shortly as I wrote him a second letter at Christmas time. I will
therefore postpone my reply to you as the whole thing hinges on whether we can get
the camp site.

Now as to your interesting story. I should be delighted to let you use
whatever you want of any material that I have sent you and as soon as I hear from
the owner of Camp Lazear I will send you the tentative plans that I have for the build-
ing. I have a little rough plan drawn up which has plenty of wall space for exhibits,
paintings, dioramas, models, photographs, maps, medals, etc.

As to your suggestion that one of your wealthy friends or your classmates at
Williams College might be interested in helping to erect a suitable memorial, I am
most interested. At this time I cannot give you a definite answer because I am myself
in the process of trying to find out how much money is needed and what can be done.
One individual has given me a thousand dollars. I have a promise of some more money
from another individual. The one hitch to your plan is that, regardless of who gives
the money, this Camp Lazear Memorial must be dedicated not to those who give the money
but to Finlay, Lazear, Reed et al. One of the purposes of my plan for the memorial is
to bring the Americans and Cubans together and stop this silly squabble over whether
Finlay or Reed should have the greatest credit. Therefore, the camp must be dedicated
to them. I greatly doubt whether it could be dedicated to the memory of any donor or
donors. At the very most, on the memorial tablet at the bottom, one might be permitted
to say “This building erected through the generosity of so and so.” Please do not
consider that I am discouraging you the least bit in your plan. It is indeed wonderful
of you to be so thoughtful and generous and to take so much of your time in starting
Dr. James E. Peabody
- 2 -
January 6, 1942
another campaign. Your previous campain was so eminently successful that we
certainly need your interest in this one.

May we leave the matter for the moment until I hear, I am sure in the
next few days, from Cuba?
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
